caption:

With the help of Tasmanian endurance rider @oneflukeshot, Payson pieced together a 360 mile route across Tasmania that crescendoed in difficulty, beginning on the wild, largely uninhabited northwestern coast and concluded on the white sand beaches of the Bay of Fires after 32 hours and over 34,000 feet of climbing. 

The island brought him face-to-face with three Tiger Snakes, one of the most venomous on the planet, hundreds of wallabies and wombats, and the friendly locals of Tasmania's rural communities.

Did you know that weâ€™re proud members of @conservationalliance who recently announced the Dolores River in Colorado as one of their four Advocacy Priority Campaigns for 2022? Beginning high in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado, it flows 230 miles until it joins the Colorado River in Utahâ€™s red rock desert near Moab. McPhee Dam and Reservoir were built in the 1980â€™s to support the growing agricultural communities in the region, and to provide much-needed water for the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in Towaoc. 

This year, they will be joining groups advocating for protection of the lower Dolores River through:

ğŸ’¦  A bill to designate a 75,000-acre National Conservation Area spanning from the base of McPhee Reservoir to the San Miguel/Montrose County line, which includes more than 70 miles of the Dolores River, establishes the Ponderosa Gorge Roadless Area, and protects special river values.

Theyâ€™re partnering with Dolores River Boating Advocates in the effort to protect this beautiful river and surrounding lands.

In an effort to bring more opportunity, diversity, and inclusivity to winter outdoor recreation spaces, #OspreyAthlete, Jessica Baker (@skidiva), will offer the 2nd annual ski camp specifically for Black, Indigenous, and Women of Color (BIWOC), from March 11-13, 2022. Attendees will spend three days skiing in the Tetons near Jackson, WY learning how to ski or improving their skills if already an experienced skier. The final day of the camp will feature a backcountry component including avalanche education, and how to safely travel in the backcountry. Osprey, along with supporting sponsors, are pitching in to offer several full-ride scholarships for women to attend this camp. "What advice would you give to someone whoâ€™s JUST getting started hiking, to encourage and support them?

I began my hiking career on the trails at Oconee Forest Park, a small wooded area behind the intramural sports fields at the University of Georgia. I didnâ€™t really know what hiking was back then, and I didnâ€™t own 'hiking clothes' or trail maps. It was basically impossible to get lost there, due to the small nature of it and the fact that every trail led back to a parking lot. I spent countless hours winding through the woods with my dogs, the trees a refuge from having my nose in textbooks and sitting under fluorescent lights in classrooms. There were no grand views, waterfalls, or picturesque destinations. Just woods, a stream, bugs and wildlife, and dirt beneath my feet.

My biggest piece of advice for someone whoâ€™s just starting is to just GO. The destination doesnâ€™t have to be awe-inspiring. The hike doesnâ€™t have to be epic. If you donâ€™t know how to read a map, go where you donâ€™t need one. You donâ€™t have to have the best gear or even the right shoes. Find a safe wooded area near your home, wear whatever you already own, lace up whatever shoes youâ€™ve got, and take a walk. Spend time with dirt under your feet and wind on your skin. Taste and smell the aroma of the trees and plants around you. Get used to the way your body moves on uneven terrain. Find your stride. Learn your pace and your stamina. Start where youâ€™re at." - @adventurelikeagirl | ğŸ“· by @emtrod90 | Featured pack from the Manta/Mira Series

Not only is this a landmark decision for the conservation of these cherished monumentsâ€”it is a tremendous win for the Native Americans, whose culture, history and heritage are tied to and preserved throughout these sacred places, as well as our partners who are committed to the protection of our public lands. 

We cannot be more proud of the Bears Ears Inter-Tribal Coalitionâ€”the many tribes whose voices have been heardâ€”for fighting for this decision, and of our first Native American Secretary of the Interior, Deb Haaland, who helped advocate for their cause. In 2019, #OspreyAmbassador @kyehalpin along with @freddy.most set out to find a creative route through the Tetons. The popular Teton Crest Trail covers the southern portion of the range but the northern section is a vast, often unexplored expanse with vague, undeveloped trails and difficult terrain. Their vision was to find a route traveling the entire length of the Tetons along the hydrological divide - the line where the water flows from either the west or the east. 

Following this line through the Tetons proved to be more of a challenge than either of them had expected and pushed them to the edge of their physical and psychological boundaries. Watch Teton Center Punch in full via the link in our bio.

Our expertise in designing backpacks dates back to 1974, when Osprey was founded on designing custom packs for mountaineers headed to the Sierra. While nearby National Parks like Zion, Bryce, Arches, Capitol Reef, and Canyonlands get most the fanfare, southern Utahâ€™s true hidden gem is Escalante, a weird, massive, and desolate landscape. Bordered by the aforementioned parks, the Colorado River on the east and Lake Powell to the south, the federally designated National Monument sprawls over hundreds of miles of rocks, sand, cactus, and the occasional oasis. 
â€”
To see the area, our group of 8 decided to tackle a 4-day bikepacking trip around the southern Utah desert. We would travel on a mix of roadsâ€“everything from rough gravel to paved highways, and try to camp near water sources so that weâ€™d be able to cook each night. We ended up getting a bit more than we bargained forâ€“280 miles in the desert sun will make your mind spinâ€“but through the process and long days in the saddle, we learned something about ourselves and each other.Â

â€œLet me ask you something,â€ one hand resting on the trekking pole that rested on his hip. â€œWhy do you backpack? I mean, whoâ€”â€ he trailed off.
â€”
When I first hiked a section of NuÌˆuÌˆmuÌˆ Poyo (the â€œpeopleâ€™s trailâ€ in the Paiute language, also called the John Muir Trail) in 2014, I had just read Wild by Cheryl Strayed. A few years before, Iâ€™d read A Walk in the Woods by Bill Bryson. Iâ€™d read John Krakauerâ€™s Into the Wild. Iâ€™d read Alfred Lansingâ€™s Endurance. As a kid, Iâ€™d read and re-read My Side of the Mountain by Jean Craighead George. In 2014, these were my teachers: the people who ushered me into an idea of nature that I found both compelling and exclusive. I loved these books, and they confused me. I knew in my body that land and race and politics and nature are all lyrics to the same song, but it felt like every time these writers talked about going outside, they didnâ€™t say boo about how white their version of outside was.
â€”
And I return the question to anyone who spends time outside: Who taught you how to be outside? Who teaches you? If your answer is a list of white men or women, know that your understanding of nature is incomplete and impoverished. Read Black, Indigenous, and Asian writers. Support organizations like @indigenouswomenhike , @outdoorafro, @wilddiversity, or @queernature that are working to shift narratives about the outdoors. Go outside, not as an escape from the world and its people, but as a way to connect with all of life more deeply.  Click the link in our bio to read Endria's compelling piece about going to nature to be in the world, not escape it.Â Â  ğŸ“· by: @endriaraa + @narinda___ |#ospreypacks #nature #natureheals

A remembrance is the type of post you never want to write. As outdoor enthusiasts, we often push our limits for the love of nature and occasionally, accidents happen.
â€”
On Sunday August 16th, Osprey ambassador David Xiao was climbing with a partner on Mount Sir Donald near Revelstoke when he fell to his death.  Tuesday would have been his 26th birthday.
â€”
David had an infectious smile and shared his love of the outdoors with everyone he met. From climbing to skiing to thru-hiking, adventure was in his bones. He had a kind and curious soul; the type that radiates positivity and inspires you to try new things. From the lens of his camera, he passionately shared his adventures with us all, so that we too would fall in love with what he loved most.
â€”
â€œI was born and raised within a city of concrete and steel in China and never felt a connection to the outdoors as a kid. I remember the first time my friends took me on a hike after moving to Canada 12 years ago. To my surprise, a hike in the Canadian Rockies meant going out and climbing a mountain, not a walk in the park. I can still picture myself sitting on top of a ridge, mesmerized by the surrounding beauty, the freedom, the joy. I was introduced to a whole new world, a side of reality I never knew existed.â€
â€”
As an Osprey ambassador, we had the joy of helping David pursue his passion for outdoor adventure. When he would talk about the PCT, he lit up. He jumped at every opportunity to share his expertise and knowledge if it would help somebody else try it for the first time.
â€”
When asked if he could make a 20 second phone call to himself at any point in your life, when would you call and what would you say,â€ his response was: To my 14-year-old self: Hey, you know that activity where people strap planks to their feet and slide down mountains really really fast? Sounds silly now but turns out you love it. Go try it now, trust me.
â€”
Thank you David, for sharing your love of the outdoors with so many and being part of the Osprey family. You have taught us to accept any challenge put in our path and to love big. We miss you so much. Rest in peace â€“ may there be many mountains in Heaven for you to climb.
Good friends and great adventures. Tag your adventure pal in the comments! ğŸ“· by: @danholzphoto  Featured pack from the Archeon Series #ospreypacks #thegooddaysaremade

For the past couple weeks, we paused our posts to listen and support the black community and the many black voices that need to be heard. During this time, a global movement took place, inspiring a critical, long-overdue conversation and the beginning of much-needed systems change.
â€”
As an immediate small step, we donated to two organizations that work tirelessly to address the root causes of social injustice and systemic racism in America: NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. (@naacp) and Color of Change (@colorofchange).
â€”
Moving forward, and with a heightened sense of purpose, we will continue the longstanding relationships we have with Black, Indigenous and People of Colorâ€¯(BIPOC)-focused organizations, like @outdoorafro, @navajo_yes, @latinooutdoors, and more; partner with content creators of color to highlight their work; use our platform to promote BIPOC voices in our blog and social channels; and hold internal meetings to evaluate and identify areas within our business that can be improved.
â€”
Within Osprey, we have been listening to the conversation, asking tough questions, educating ourselves and developing an action plan to make all communities feel safe, welcome and heard. Our DEI committee has a three-year roadmap in place that includes employee and manager training, department reviews, updated hiring practices, policy and procedure analysis, vision creation and employee culture surveys.
â€”
It has been a longstanding goal at Osprey to promote a more diverse community in the outdoorsâ€”and we are committed to the internal, long-term work required to further transform outdoor spaces into a more inclusive environment.

â€œIt seems to me that the natural world is the greatest source of excitement; the greatest source of visual beauty; the greatest source of intellectual interest. It is the greatest source of so much in life that makes life worth living.â€ â€“ David Attenborough | ğŸ“· by: @danholzphoto | Featured pack from the Archeon Series #ospreypacks #thegooddaysaremade #sustainability

At our core, we are steadfast in our resolve to leave our world better than we found it. Because of that, weâ€™re choosing not to stay silent on the events of this past week and our nationâ€™s long history of systemic racism. We believe there is simply no place for hatred in our communities, in our outdoor spacesâ€”anywhere in the world, period. We stand with the black community to condemn senseless deaths and injustices that permeate all facets of our society.
â€”
We realize sharing our beliefs is a small step, and weâ€™re pushing ourselves to do better. Better starts with listening more and developing an evolving action plan.
â€”
Starting today, we plan to use our platform for good and to ensure BIPOC voices are heardâ€”that means giving them a platform to speak about experiences, better representing people of color through all of our stories and diversifying the non-profits we partner with to better support our core values.
â€”
Our community is open and inclusive to all. Our differences fuel our strengths. Together we can end inequalityâ€”and we have no patience for those who say thatâ€™s impossible.
â€”
Black Lives Matter. â€”
#blackouttuesday #blackoutday2020

"A little while back, I was able to take my daughter on this trip down the Caprock Canyons State Park Trailway. Easing this kid into more self-sufficiency has been a great experience, and she has really started to come into her own this year. We rode 13 gradually descending miles to the campsite on the western side of the Clarity Tunnel. We had a headwind, the temperature was never above 38 F, and mist and drops of rain were an occasional element. Although we stopped to grab a snack and explore a bit of the trailwayâ€™s history, we didnâ€™t dottle, and Eva kept the pace moving. Like most kids, one of the more fun parts of camping is getting to and setting your site up. She wanted to be there. But, like most cyclists, she also wanted to simply put her head down and move through less than ideal conditions to our destination.
.
.
She never once complained, and after getting to camp, was nothing but a walking smile, briefly checking out the tunnel we we would explore the next morning, raiding the larder on my bike (even though she carried all her food on hers), and watching the mist and rain roll over the hills roughly undulating away from the Caprock Escarpment."
.
.

.â â €

Dear Osprey friends and family,

In recent days weâ€™ve been contacted by a number of you, faithful customers, sharing your stories of adventures delayed or rerouted close to home, even backyards. You sent photos of packed Osprey bags waiting patiently by the front door. You have shown determination, passion and grit, you have inspired us with your fortitude. You have also reminded us how important empathy is in times of crisis because all of you are telling us that you are not giving up. And neither would we. This bit of defiance, this statement of hope will serve as a guiding light for us here at Osprey. Your determination inspires us to take one step forward and then another. This trail is one we hike together.

During this time, osprey.com is open and all orders will ship free. To help support our retail partners, our dealer service team is taking orders and our dealer locator provides an up-to-date view of local store hours, inventory, curbside pick-up and same-day delivery options. Our distribution center is shipping everything.

For our Osprey team and the communities in which we operate, we have pivoted our priorities to prevent the spread of COVID-19. We have implemented a temporary telecommuting policy in our U.S. and European offices. If a role must be performed on-site, we are actively practicing social distancing, increased sanitization, and ensuring safe work environments and practices.

While our love of adventure has not dwindled in this trying time, we are finding moments to celebrate the outdoors responsibly. We believe adventure is open to anyone and found everywhereâ€”even, and especially, in your own backyard.

As the situation evolves, we are doing our best to stay current and support the communities, partners and relationships we have fostered through our 46 years of business.

Please keep sending us your stories. How are you changing it up without giving it up? Weâ€™ll share the best ones with our audience to inspire. Whether youâ€™re summiting lofty peaks in remote basement pillow forts or venturing out for everyday essentialsâ€”keep sharing because like you to us, we promise to remain faithfully at your side and together we shall prevail.

My friend flew up for the weekend from LA and I promised him (at least a taste of) Washington outdoors. So on Sunday morning, we made the drive through bursts of rainfall and waning sunlight to the Central Cascades. Just as we arrived at the trailhead, it began to snow. As the clouds rolled in, I was afraid we were doomed to a cold and viewless hike (though it would have been a perfectly appropriate version of Washington outdoors.) Luckily, however, the blue sky never left us completely and the day turned out to be stunning. Cold. But stunning. â£â£
â£â£
Iâ€™ve done this hike before and yet - I found myself standing motionless on the ridgeline, mesmerized by snowy Mt. Stuart. Four of my girlfriends and I spent four days backpacking on the Via Dinarica from outside of Sarajevo to Sutjeska National Park in Bosnia. We saw zero other hikers on the trail the entire way. ZERO! In a land that could be compared in many ways to Yosemite, it was hard to believe that we had it all to ourselves, especially with the fall colors, perfect hiking temps, and sunshine.

During our trip, we met many warm locals who were eager to help us, talk to us (even without sharing a common tongue), and of course share their rakija and food with us. Aside from plenty of bonding time for our friendships to grow even stronger, we rested a LOT, laughed a LOT, slowed life down, put away our phones, and enjoyed getting far (VERY far) off the beaten path, together.

I needed that time desperately, and I'm so grateful to have had the opportunity to finally experience a section of the Via Dinarica with my badass female dream team. | ğŸ“·@travelingjackie | Featured pack from the Farpoint/Fairview, Levity/Lumina Series #ospreypacks #ospreyambassador

This summer, a friend and I decided to go for an impromptu overnight camping trip on the summit of a nearby mountain called Mt. English. After bushwhacking for a few hours from the end of a logging road, we came to some beautiful alpine meadows with the wildflowers in full bloom. From here, we made our way up some scree, scrambled to the summit, and got cozy in our sleeping bags for the night. I stayed up and watched the milky way rise about the surrounding mountains on a moonless night-- it was so serene. I woke to frost on my sleeping bag and the sky slowly changing into hues of orange and red. This photo was taken just before leaving the summit, overlooking the glacier below. After that, it was back to the car because my friend had to rush so he wouldn't be late for work that day. All in all, it was a successful mini-adventure. - Vince Schnabl, Osprey Ambassador#ospreypacks | ğŸ“·@vincentschnabl | Featured pack from the Rook/Renn Series #ospreypacks #ospreyambassador
"It's not the mountain we conquer, but ourselves." - Sir Edmund Hillary | ğŸ“·@danpatitucci | Featured pack from the Manta/Mira Series #ospreypacks

"Iron Goat Trail off of Highway 2, just before Stevens Pass is one of my favorite day hikes to do when itâ€™s hot out. Itâ€™s shaded (thanks to the tree cover and snowsheds) and is relatively flat for most of the trail. There are multiple ways to hike this trail. I always like to start from the trailhead at the red caboose, right off the highway and hike the 6 miles into Wellington, making it a 12 mile roundtrip hike. Along the way, youâ€™ll pass the Windy Point viewpoint, the old snowsheds and the long tunnel going into Wellington. As you make your way towards Wellington, the interpretive signs will teach you all about the history of the old Great Northern Railroad and the Wellington Avalanche Disaster, which was the worst avalanche in the history of the United States in 1910, killing a total of 96 people." - Kathleen Neves, Osprey Ambassador | ğŸ“· @kathleenlovesyoga | Featured pack from the Exos/Eja Series #ospreypacks #ospreyambassador

Follow along to  learn more! | Music for Free was a self-supported musical tour by bike in which I rode 3000 miles down the Continental Divide from Banff, Canada to Antelope Wells, New Mexico. I carried my guitar and banjo on my bike giving free concerts to the people along the way. I was joined by filmmaker Keenan Desplanques who helped document the stories of the people I sang for. We completed the 3000 mile ride with 15 performances in 30 days. What follows are images from the Music for Free trip accompanied by my thoughts looking back on what the journey was about. Music for Free is about connecting athletic and artistic identities. Often timeâ€™s artist and athlete are not seen as one. I see little separation. The same thing that compels me to ride 150 miles through the dirt in a day, is that same thing that leaves me inspired to play a show at the end of that ride. The same mysterious force that brings forth creative acts is the same power that enables us to embrace the unknown in the middle of a blizzard, follow the uncertainties down a set of rapids, or trust our intuition hanging on the side of a piece of granite. Itâ€™s about listening to the louder voices that expand with possibility in the landscape around us. Making beautiful things out of the truth that within the unknown, the greatest moments of await. | ğŸ“·: @benweavermusic + @keendes | Featured pack from the Raptor/Raven Series #ospreypacks #musicforfree

Music for Free is about wildness. How does wildness differ from wilderness? How do we relate to wildness both inner and outer? How does our relationship to wildness connect to our ability to protect public land? Is wildness an inherent quality in all living things that connects each of us to each other, as well as all the other-than-human members of the ecosystems we share this planet with? Music for Free is about discovering and celebrating where our wildness overlap. It is about the rivers. The Grizzly. The Porcupine. The Columbine. The remaining glaciers, and listening to the wisdom they have to impart on us as we move through their homes. Music for Free is about honoring and strengthening relationships, it is about getting as close to the dark as an owl. Music for Free is about moving at the pace of the land. | ğŸ“·: @benweavermusic +@keendes | Featured pack from the Raptor/Raven Series |#ospreypacks #musicforfree

Change does not come from the middle. It comes from the edges. The bike leaves me spending an incredible amount of my time on the edge. Metaphorically, and literally speaking. I ride the edge of the road, this human made surface placed on top of and running through the natural systems. The edge of the road is a space of transition. The place where constant speed and progress butt right up against the rivers, trees and wild flowers. Music for Free is about living in that space at the edge and bringing some of its truth and magic a little closer to the middle. We discovered incredible people, with incredible truths, living among the remaining wild spaces of this landscape. In hindsight it should be no surprise. The miraculousness of your discoveries coincide with the miraculousness of the places you seek them out. The continental divide is the head waters of miraculousness in my opinion. | ğŸ“·: @benweavermusic +@keendes | Featured pack from the Raptor/Raven Series #ospreypacks #musicforfree
Spontaneity is the best kind of adventure. | ğŸ“· @mike.karas | Featured pack from the Hikelite Series #ospreypacks

Music for Free is for the people. Specifically the people who live along the Continental Divide. More specifically members of the communities through which the Great Divide Mountain Bike Route, the Tour Divide and the Continental Divide Trail pass through. Music for Free is about the wildness and spirit of these people who live with this land by choice and make their lives how they want them to be. Music for free is a gift back and thank you to those that have given so much to those out seeking adventure. Music for Free is meant to honor the truth that under the soil our roots are all bound together. Even though water that falls on the divide ends up in opposing oceans it will all one day come back to touch the dirt as rain. Music for Free is to remind us that we are all connected and that strength and resilience of any system rests in its diversity. | ğŸ“·: @benweavermusic + @keendes | Featured pack from the Raptor/Raven Series #ospreypacks #musicforfree

Did you know the idea for @smokeybear came about on August 9, 1944 and the bear quickly became a symbol for forest fire prevention. March 17 - 20, 2021

(Post 2 of 2)

On St. Patrick's Day, Robert, the manager of the Palace Hotel, gave us a ride back to the trailhead in the Pinos Altos, where Freebird had left off at the other day. We weren't walking far today, and were hoping to at least make it to Our Lady of Guadalupe Monastery for Vespers that evening. I don't recall the mileage there from the trailhead, but I think it was more or less 5 miles. We walked leisurely all afternoon, stopping to talk with a trail maintainer for a few hours. At that point we thought we were actually going to be late, but we found the side trail to the monastery and made it just in time. Brother Lawrence radiantly greeted us at the gift shop. He left and returned with bottled water, two Ziploc bags of apples and oranges, a box of electrolyte mixes, a bag of their Irish blend coffee (the monks there roast and sell coffee), and two Benedictine medals with an accompanying booklet about the saint. Lawrence gave us directions on how to locate our friend Doug the Hermit (See previous post: https://www.instagram.com/p/CuRyDkbLZxC/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link&igsh=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==), whose place was off of our maps this year. We stayed for Vespers and then dropped back down the side trail, finding a place to camp on a ridge.

The next day the CDT circled around the monastery. We couldn't find the turnoff that led to Doug's place, so we continued on our route into the eastern end of the Pinos Altos. We crossed Highway 15, just north of Pinos Altos town, and camped in a ponderosa forest. On the 19th, a couple day-hikers from Silver City joined us for lunch. We gave them the coffee from Brother Lawrence, as we had no way of brewing it, nor did we want to carry that much.

(Story continued in comments)

Adirondack Mountains

Winter backpacking trek with the homie @kuehl_hauls . Trekked up Mt. Colden with no trail in sight and forged new paths via glissading down. Packed out in a lean-to for a night near Avalanche Pass and embraced the reward of a zero-degree night. 

#Backpacking #wintertrek #adirondacks #camping #trekking

We have two spot openings on our Cumberland Island National Seashore project! Located in coastal Georgia, this unique and beautiful location has maritime forests, undeveloped beaches, and wide marshes. There's a lot of history here and a lot to learn. 

Our volunteer crew will take the ferry to the island where we'll spend the week working on trail maintenance, vegetation removal/management, and other projects. Learn more about this project and sign up by clicking the "2024 Projects" link in our bio!

Just five hours north of San Francisco sits a gem of the backpacking world, The Lost Coast. Never in my wildest dreams did I imagine I would find such a remote and spectacular coastal destination in the most populous state in the US.

For five days we experienced mile after mile of pristine black sand beaches, old growth redwoods, herds of elk, barking sea lions, and the sound of ocean waves soothing us to sleep. We had the sense that we travelled to the far reaches of the earth, but strangely, no one stamped our passports. Repost: @rachid.dahnoun

Gym Review #3 

SciFitness 

A gym as uninspiring as the city itself. I havenâ€™t been to many places that Iâ€™d absolutely never return to but Cebu is definitely one of them and this gym unfortunately followed in its cityâ€™s footstep. 

The gym itself is located on the third floor of a run down building on a busy street. On first impressions the actual gym looked like a good place to workout and at 100 pesos was very cheap, however, SciFitnessâ€™s biggest problem is that it is like working out in a Sauna with the demotivating music of Taylor Swift in the background. The heat and the music choice combined both contributed to a negative workout atmosphere. Donâ€™t get me wrong the Philippines is a hot place but the lack of air con or open windows made working out for longer than 10 minutes and not ending up in a sweaty dripping mess nearly impossible. 

There are some positives to the gym though if you can bare the heat. 
1. The price is cheap.
2. There is a fair amount of equipment available and everything worked.
3. The staff are friendly and helpful. 

On the whole SciFitness has negative and positives if you want a cheap workout, can handle the heat and Taylor swift is your choice of workout music then SciFitness is for you.

#backpacking #ultralightbackpacking

Itâ€™s almost 8 years since we quit the 9-5  life to travel the world, so I thought Iâ€™d share 8 important things Iâ€™ve learned along the way â¤ï¸

1. Planning helps you discover hidden gems, but booking makes you rigid. Allow for spontaneity and flexibility with your plans and donâ€™t book everything in advance. 

2. The connections you make on the road are deeper than you can imagine, and the people you meet understand you on a level that others canâ€™t understand ğŸ«¶ğŸ» if youâ€™re feeling like youâ€™ve not met your tribe yet, solo travel! 

3. You need a lot less than you think you do. All the clutter and *stuff* that comes with a â€˜settledâ€™ life loses meaning, and you realise you need very little to be happy ğŸ˜Š

4. Travelling together makes your relationship more solid. We had to adjust to travelling together, and now we have such a great flow with travel that I hate doing it without him! 

5.  You have to go with an open mind to get the true benefits of travel. Try as many new experiences as you can, talk to everyone, eat everything, and donâ€™t be afraid to look stupid or ask questions. Itâ€™s part of the process! 

6. Be able to say yes, no, hello, please, and thank you in the local language. It invites conversation and shows a willingness to learn about the culture! Think of how much youâ€™ll learn over the years â¤ï¸ 

7. Youâ€™ll only be nervous for a little bit, then your confidence will grow and youâ€™ll be unstoppable! 

8. Itâ€™s not as hard or expensive as you think. Your mind just like to worry too much! 

Travel will grow your mind, change your outlook / goals / ambitions, and introduce you to the best people â¤ï¸ Long term travellers, is there anything you would add?
